required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Efficacy and Safety of Sphenopalatine Ganglion Pulsed Radiofrequency Treatment for Cluster Headache
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Multicentre, Randomized, Controlled, Blinded-endpoint Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Sphenopalatine Ganglion Pulsed Radiofrequency Treatment for Cluster Headache

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators aim to investigate the effectiveness and safety of sphenopalatine ganglion pulsed radiofrequency on cluster headache.

detailed_description.textblock: The investigators aim to investigate whether the sphenopalatine ganglion pulsed radiofrequency treatment is better than traditional sphenopalatine ganglion nerve block technology and provides medical evidence for the clinical application and promotion of sphenopalatine ganglion pulsed radiofrequency treatment to provide a minimally invasive, safe, and effective treatment for patients with cluster headache who do not respond to drug treatment.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Within 1 year (the cluster period is not over 3 months generally)
primary_outcome.description: The duration of the cluster period is defined as the total duration of the headache, including the pain attack time before and after treatment.

secondary_outcome.measure: The degree of pain during headache attacks after treatment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day, 3 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluated by numeric rating scale (NRS, 0 points for no pain and 10 points for the most severe pain)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day, 3 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: The number of attacks per day

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day, 3 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Duration of each headache attack after treatment

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day, 3 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Dose of auxiliary analgesic drugs per day

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day, 3 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: From the end of this cluster period to the beginning of the next cluster period

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day, 3 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Patient satisfactory scale (PSS) evaluation (0 for unsatisfactory, and 10 for very satisfied).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 day, 3 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year after surgery
secondary_outcome.description: The effectiveness rate is calculated as follows: effectiveness rate = the number of effective patients / total number of patients in this group × 100%.

arm_group.description: This group will undergo pulsed radiofrequency treatment.
This group will undergo nerve block treatment.

intervention.description: The pulse treatment generator (PMF-21-100-5, Baylis Medical Inc., Montreal, Canada) with a length of 10 cm, 21-gauge, and an active tip length of 5 mm is inserted vertically into the puncture point. The pulse treatment generator is set to the pulsed radiofrequency automatic mode, with a temperature of 42 °C, pulse frequency of 2 Hz, pulse width of 20 ms, and treatment duration of 360s.
A mixture of 40 mg Triamcinolone + 2 ml of 1% Bupivacaine + 2 ml of 2% mepivacaine + 1:100000 epinephrine is injected for nerve block treatment using a puncture needle.
